thesis.description: Ethics has been described as the science of morality and conduct. [...] Ethics then must deal with the inner process and the outward behaviour as to whether both is right or wrong, good or bad. ...a question of Ethics is to decide which is the highest category, the "content" or the "attitude", and which is primary character or conduct. But this much seems apparent that no act is moral which does not combine both. [...] That faith in a moral ideal is at the root of all morality needs hardly to be proven. [...] There seems to be as much conviction also that this good is the end or purpose of human life. [...] The business of Ethics, then, is to conduct a systematic examination of the various ideals of human life, and to seek to correlate them with the true or absolute ideal of humanity, so that at last the absolute good is discovered. The Ethics of Achievement is such an attempt.
thesis.creator: Kelloway, Warwick Freeman.
thesis.subject: ETHICS.
Philosophy.
thesis.title: The ethics of achievement.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Just as in the study of the effect of external conditions, such as pressure and temperature, on gases made possible the enunciation of the gas laws and subsequently the molecular theory, so it is only by investigation of the effect of varying external conditions on solution and related phenomena that we can hope to arrive at the true mechanism of solution, which itself is no doubt closely related to chemical reaction. [...]
thesis.creator: Larose, Paul.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The diffusion of gases through metals.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The rapidly increasing growth of the nation's power load will in a few years have exhausted, or nearly so, the available output of the developable water powers near the load centres, and as the demand for power will still increase, it will be necessary to make use of water powers at great distances from the load, and transmission lines of 200, 300, and even 500 miles in length will not be uncommon. For lines of such lengths, the highest operating voltages must be used, and in order to justify the great expense of building these long lines, large blocks of power must be transmitted, of the order of 100,000 kilowatts per circuit. The calculation of the electrical characteristics of these lines must take into account the distributed nature of the self inductance and electrostatic capacity, that is, no approximations are justifiable as with shorter lines, and rigorous solutions must be employed. [...]
thesis.creator: LeNeveu, Arthur Philip Cooke.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: The transmission of power at high voltages over long distances.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: One of the greatest difficulties that has confronted the field experimentalist is that of soil variability or soil variation.To overcome this source of error, that is, to reduce plot variability, extensive studies have been made by a number of workers. Various suggestions have been put forward, such as the use of check plots, replication, long narrow rather than short wide plots. [...]
thesis.creator: Liebenberg, Louis C.
thesis.subject: Field experiments.
Field crops.
Agronomy.
thesis.title: The relation of plot yields in one year with those of succeeding years.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In conducting breeding work with oats, some of the material, specially that used for hybridizing and the first generation, is frequently grown in a greenhouse during the winter. Under such conditions a greater ease in handling the material obtains. As a greater control of the environment is possible in the greenhouse than in the field more uniform results can be obtained from the actual process of artificial cross-pollination. Frequently only a few hybrid seeds are produced, and as it is desired to develop as many second generation plants as is possible, it is necessary to have conditions which will favor both the germination of all the hybrid seeds and a good development of the first generation plants. The use of greenhouses has been found valuable in obtaining these results.[...]
thesis.creator: Lods, Emile A.
thesis.subject: Artificial light gardening.
Oats -- Breeding.
Agronomy.
Plants -- Effect of light on.
thesis.title: A study of the influence of electric light used to supplement daylight on oats grown as breeding material in the greenhouse during the winter season.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: To most law-abiding citizens crime is an abstract thing - a state of affairs that is far off, distant, unreal. It does not touch them directly; they are not intimately concerned with it. To them the criminal is an unnatural being living in a world whereof they have no knowledge, or at most a very superficial knowledge. Their attitude towards him is likely one of benevolent compassion, or benign pity. On the subject of the corrective measures employed their attitude is apathetic, or else violently partisan. If however, it should come about that they are victims of these criminals, the whole question assumes an entirely different aspect. Then, it is to them a matter of vital concern that the guilty ones be apprehended and brought to justice. When one is vitally concerned with some problem that problem becomes supremely important. To understand the criminal we must see him as he lives, and performs his dastardly deeds. He must be considered in the concrete, not in the abstract.[...]
thesis.creator: MacLennan, M. C. (Malcolm Cameron).
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Crime and criminals in English and French memoirs.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The following study of the correlation of seasonal egg production with total annual egg yield of Barred Plymouth Rock fowl is the result of an analysis of the egg records secured during the four years, 1919 - 1923 inclusive, at the Canadian Egg Laying Contest conducted by the Experimental Farms system at Ottawa, Canada. The stock in such a contest,which is open to the world for egg laying competition,represents selected flocks from a large number of different poultry breeders, most of which are Canadian, whilst some come from the United States of America. Since the egg production comes from a group of selected pens it is not as representative for the Barred Plymouth Rock breed as it would be had all the birds used been from one line of breeding. Nevertheless, since all the pens were under exactly the same neutral management the results obtained should be fairly accurate and useful for such a study.[...]
thesis.creator: Maw, William Alfred, 1893-1964.
thesis.subject: Poultry Husbandry.
Plymouth Rock chicken.
Eggs -- Production.
thesis.title: The seasonal variation in egg production in the barred Plymouth Rock fowl.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The movements which an animal makes to rotation about any axis are called compensatory, and as indicated by Maxwell have two main characteristics; (1) to retain the original field of vision; (2) to restore the body to its original orientation in space. If a frog is turned about a vertical axis to the right it will turn its head and walk round to the left, when rotation is stopped, the head swings round to the right and the animal may make several turns to the right before coming to rest. [...]
thesis.creator: McNally, William James, 1897-.
thesis.subject: Frogs.
Labyrinth (Ear).
Physiology.
thesis.title: Experiments on the labyrinth of the frog.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The periodic system of Mendeleieff and Lothar Meyer, showed the existence of relationships among the elements and indicated clearly enough that the origin of such relationships was to be sought in the structure of the individual atoms themselves. As spectroscopic analysis was developed, astronomers observed that in the nebulae, only the lightest elements, hydrogen and helium, were to be found, while in the spectra of the stars, the heavier elements progressively made their appearance; the newer and hotter stars were composed mainly of the lighter elements; the heavier ones appeared in the older and colder stars. This suggested the evolution of the elements from some primal, simple form of matter which was called "protyle".[...]
thesis.creator: Mennie, John H.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Vapor densities and molecular attraction.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In nearly all ore dressing operations the material has first to be crushed to a greater or less extent, and in many cases, it has to be ground very fine. Fine crushing of any brittle substance invariably produces a considerable amount of exceedingly minute particles. The fine material thus produced is usually mixed with water either during the crushing or in subsequent operations, and the portion of this water-ore mixture which is too fine to clarify immediately on settling is commonly called slime. The settlement of slime is therefore an essential problem in modern ore dressing.[...]
thesis.creator: Muir, Allan K.
thesis.subject: Ore Dressing.
thesis.title: The settling of very finely divided material in water, and certain dilute akali solutions, with especial reference to decantation methods in ore dressing.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The history of "the city of the violet crown" was enriched by Pericles; in a less degree the grey citadel of Quebec felt the impress of James Murray's personality. In order to understand the course of events during the pregnant years of early British rule in Canada, the character of the first British governor must be considered, for he undoubtedly exercised a paramount influence at the time, though it was not that of a Pitt.[...]
thesis.creator: Nichol, Jean.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: James Murray, military initiator of British civil government in Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: For many years metallurgists have endeavoured to find a suitable method of utilizing the immense deposits of Ilmenite and Titaniferous iron ores that occur in different parts of the world, particularly in Norway, the United States, and Quebec.The early attempts were for the recovery of the iron by smelting methods. The smelting of low grade titaniferous ores, e.g.,those containing in the neighborhood of 3% Ti, can be accomplished without difficulty. Rossi has shown that by altering the composition of the flux and increasing the fuel consumption, ores containing as much as 16% of Ti can be smelted satisfactorily, and a slag produced which is as fluid as that obtained in ordinary commercial blast furnace practice.[...]
thesis.creator: Powell, Allan T.
thesis.subject: Metallurgy
thesis.title: The economic production of titanium oxide from ilmenite.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: "Whatever helps to shape the human being; to make the human being what he is, or hinder him from being what he is not,is part of his education:" All the influences with which humanity comes in contact play their part in the development or destruction of the human race. All the forces of nature in the immediate environment of the individual have their educational value in shaping character. But in the matter of education nature alone cannot be trusted to supply the neeessary requirements of a high standard of development. Our present state of civilization is the product of the efforts of millions of human beings, and it would be absurd to imagine that a child could recapitulate even a small fraction of this advance. Through education the child must receive the knowledge accumulated through centuries of growth. Therefore the state and continuance of civilization in a nation depends upon the education of its youth.[...]
thesis.creator: Read, M. Gwendolen Ellery (Mary Gwendolen Ellery).
thesis.subject: Eliot, George, 1819-1880 -- Criticism and interpretation.
Education in literature.
English.
Hardy, Thomas, 1840-1928 -- Criticism and interpretation.
Meredith, George, 1828-1909 -- Criticism and interpretation.
thesis.title: The treatment of education in the novels of George Eliot, George Meredith and Thomas Hardy.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: To chronicle the annals of Canadian journalism in all its many and varied aspects would be a task requiring many months of labour involving the minutest research. To the average reader this statement might be looked upon as absurd, for Canadian journalism is often regarded as being something extremely recent, something that is more of the present than of the past. Yet when one begins to delve into the records of newspaper activity in Canada's provinces there comes the realization that journalistic endeavour in this country has extended over a period of many years and that the journalistic machinery of present day is only the outcome of a slow and, at times times, a painful growth. And the deeper one goes into the subject, the greater this realization becomes, for the enormousness of it is staggering and the opportunities of detailed research are almost without limit.[...]
thesis.creator: Read, Stanley M.
thesis.subject: Journalism -- Canada -- History -- 18th century.
English.
Journalism -- Canada -- History -- 19th century.
thesis.title: An account of English journalism in Canada from the middle of the eighteenth century to the beginning of the twentieth, with special emphasis being given to the periods prior to Confederation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Sulphur dioxide may be classed among those compounds which have been known from the earliest times. Its physiological action alone has characterized it throughout the ages and caused it to he associated with the nether regions. One of the first compounds whose chemical composition was well established, sulphur dioxide has not only been the subject of innumerable chemical researches but has proven to be of great commercial use. It is the basic product of some of the most important chemical industries and each year sees an increase in its production. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the properties of sulphur dioxide are well known.[...]
thesis.creator: Robertson, Carol E.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Conductivities of aqueous solutions of sulphur dioxide and other properties of sulphur dioxide.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Before discussing the flavoring principle in maple syrup,it would be appropriate to give a definition for the latter product as made by Order in Council under the Food and Drugs Act. [...]
thesis.creator: Robison, Samuel C.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The isolation and identification of the flavouring principle in maple syrup.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The problem of the elimination of error in field experiments is a very comprehensive one. So many factors may operate to influence results that it is extremely difficult to arrive at definite and accurate conclusions. The more fully the investigator is aware of the extent to which his results nay have been influenced by various combinations of factors, the less certain is he that his interpretation of results is correct. Every investigator wishes to obtain accurate data, and to have his conclusions backed by sound experimental evidence. While each investigator realizes that his data obtained from field experiments are not absolutely accurate, many treat numerous sources of errors lightly under the error are so small as to have no material effect on the ultimate results. A discussion of some of the factors which may have a direct and marked effect on results may serve to illustrate this point. Other sources of errors were overlooked for many years through lack of a knowledge of their existence, and doubtless many have yet to be discovered.[...]
thesis.creator: Schurman, David Cairns.
thesis.subject: Agronomy.
thesis.title: Methods of experimentation with corn. : Elimination of errors in plot tests.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: En étudiant le "Théâtre en liberté", nous avons trouvé les divisions suivantes qui nous paraissent logiques: La première traitera des origines, et de l'historique du Théâtre. Cette division renfermera des remarques sur le théâtre d'Alfred de Musset,-qui, comme nous tâcherons de le montrer, a été le précurseur de Victor Hugo, dans ce genre dramatique,- et les jugements de la critique contemporaine.[...]
thesis.creator: Sharples, Alice.
thesis.subject: French.
Hugo, Victor, 1802-1885 -- Criticism and interpretation.
thesis.title: Le théâtre en liberté de Victor Hugo.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Modern building construction is divided into two main types,- steel frame buildings with reinforced concrete floors, and buildings wholly constructed of reinforced concrete.In the steel frame building the steel is erected, forming a skeleton, after which the concrete floor slabs and the haunching around the beams are poured; the forms are generally supported by the steel beams themselves. The practice of supporting the forms in this way eliminates much of the falsework facilitating thereby free movement of men and materials on the floor below.This is a much safer method of construction than reinforced concrete which requires the use of falsework until the concrete is set. However, in the design of the steel frame building no consideration is given to the aduitional strength due to this encasing concrete.[...]
thesis.creator: Shaw, Gerald E.
thesis.subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics.
thesis.title: Continuity in steel I-beams haunched with concrete.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

degree.name: Master of Science
degree.discipline: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics

thesis.description: The phrase "Simultaneous leaching and electrolysis" possibly needs some explanation. A pulp containing the copper ore and the leaching solution is agitated by air or by direct mechanical means, while simultaneously with the leaching of the ore, the copper is being electrolytically deposited directly from the pulp or muddy solution. The regeneration of the solvent used, in this case, sulphuric acid, proceeds simultaneously with the déposition of the copper. The possibility of simultaneous leaching and electrolysis seems to have first occured to Body, who invented and patented the so-called Body Process in 1886. [...]
thesis.creator: Sweny, George William.
thesis.subject: Metallurgical Engineering.
thesis.title: The extraction of copper from its ores by simultaneous leaching and electrolysis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The studies on the genus Zanthium, of which this is a preliminary account, were begun in the autumn of 1922. An attempt was made to obtain seeds of Xanthium from all part of North America and thus to gain some idea of the distribution of species. It was hoped, also, that a study of the plants, from germination to maturity, would throw some new light on the taxonomy by revealing genetic relationships in the genus. An experimental garden has been devoted exclusively to Xanthium for two summers. In 1923, seeds from 22 different sources in North America, were grown. In 1924, all the seeds planted had been collected in two small areas on opposite shores of the St. Lawrence at Montreal. Small numbers of plants have been grown in the McGill University greenhouse during the winter months of both years. [...]
thesis.creator: Symons, Jennie L.
thesis.subject: Botany.
thesis.title: Physiological variations in xanthium.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The margarines, as the name implies, are compounds formed by the chemical union of glycerol and margaric acid. The chemistry of this acid has enlisted the attention and interest of scientific investigators for a great many years. Since the classical researches of Chevreul on the fats in 1815, the subject has been the cause of a great deal of discussion, and a large number of chemists have contributed their share of patient toil and untiring energy in an effort to throw some light on the matter. It would seem advisable at this point to outline briefly the history of margaric acid and trace the various vicissitudes it has experienced in the last hundred years. [...]
thesis.creator: Thomson, Walter W.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The preparation and properties of the margarines.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In the spring of 1923 the tomato crop in the commercial greenhouses at Macdonald College became infested with streak or winter blight. This disease manifested itself by streaks on the stems and petioles, a spotting, curling and shrivelling of the leaves, and irregular brown spots on the fruit, all of which resulted, in the majority of cases, in complete wilting of the whole plant. In other cases a long spindling growth of the upper part of the plant was evident. It was characterised by its sudden onset and virulent nature, and resulted in a loss of one third of the crop. This was the first time that the disease as such had been brought to the attention of the plant pathologist of the institution; but on making further enquiries it was found that a disease of apparently similar nature had infested the greenhouses some nine or ten years before. [...]
thesis.creator: Vanterpool, Thomas C.
thesis.subject: Tomatoes -- Diseases and pests.
Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Streak or winter blight of tomato in Quebec.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: [...] These poetic lines would carry us back thirteen hundred years ago to the Court of King Edward of Northumbria. The Roman Strangers had just arrived, and a crowd of eager listeners had gathered round to listen to their teaching. At last, an old warrior asked the question, "Can this new religion tell us of what happens after death? The life of man is like a sparrow flying through this lighted nail. It enters in at one door from the darkness outside, and flitting through the light and warmth,passes through the farther door into the dark unknown beyond. Can this new religion solve for us the mystery? What comes to men in the dark dim unknown?" [...]
thesis.creator: White, Harold.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The treatment of immortality by poets of the ninteenth century.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of this thesis is to make a study of the underlying principles of Moral Conduct in their relation to Reality. In all ethical attempts of the past, there was one particular at least in which they were correct, namely, that man is essentially a creature of desire, ever craving for sane ideal object. Green presents this same truth very vividly and convincingly in his theory of "seif-objectification," H (Bk.II.); and in his doctrine of the nature of consciousness, he attempts to ground this self-objectifying principle. This, in a word, will be our attempt to ground the ideal. [...]
thesis.creator: Wilkinson, George.
thesis.subject: Philosophy.
thesis.title: What is the metaphysic of ethics?
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
